sols_html:
Firstly, notice that in order for the denominator to be well defined, we require that \(\displaystyle 1-x > 0\) (strictly greater than 0 since the denominator of a fraction cannot be 0). This gives us that b has value 1 if it is to be maximal. Now, for a to be minimal, we notice that the denominator is always positive if a is less than 1 so that gives no restriction. However the numerator has to be positive in order to have a pdf and so we require that a is greater than 0. Lastly, the area condition on a pdf shows us that

\(\displaystyle 1 = \int_{0}^{1} \frac{cx}{\sqrt{1-x}} = \lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q}\frac{cx}{\sqrt{1-x}}\)

Let \(\displaystyle u = 1-x\) so that \(\displaystyle du = -dx\), \(\displaystyle u(0) = 1\), \(\displaystyle u(q) = 1-q\) and substituting gives

\[\begin{aligned} 1 &= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{cx}{\sqrt{1-x}} \\ &= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1}^{1-q}\frac{-c(1-u)}{\sqrt{u}} \\ &= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}} c\int_{1-q}^{1}(\sqrt{u}^{-1}-\sqrt{u})\,du \\ &= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}} c(2\sqrt{u} - \frac{2u^{3/2}}{3})\big|_{1-q}^{1} \\ &= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \big(c(2\sqrt{1} - \frac{2(1)^{3/2}}{3}) - c(2\sqrt{1-q} - \frac{2(1-q)^{3/2}}{3})\big)\\ &= c\left(2 - \frac{2}{3}\right)\\ &= \frac{4c}{3}\end{aligned}\]

and isolating for c gives us that \(c = 3/4\).
